head.title: Doublespeak on the Abortion Gag Rule

hedline.hl1: Doublespeak on the Abortion Gag Rule

block.p: Representative Dick Armey's letter ("Gag Rule Isn't Part of G.O.P. 'Contract,' " Nov. 1) is a fine example of political doublespeak.
Representative Dick Armey's letter ("Gag Rule Isn't Part of G.O.P. 'Contract,' " Nov. 1) is a fine example of political doublespeak.

His letter does not acknowledge the fact that a welfare reform proposal, part of the House Republican "Contract With America," would create a brand-new gag rule on abortion information. His assertion that the bill would not restore the old Reagan-Bush-era gag rule on Title X Federal family planning funds is an example of being accurate and misleading at the same time.

The proposed gag rule in the "Contract," which would be attached to Title IV A.F.D.C. funds, is every bit as objectionable and discriminatory as its Title X predecessor. That's the crux of the matter. As your editorial ("The Gag Rule, Revisited," Oct. 24) pointed out, any gag rule is unjust, compromises quality and draws a class distinction between women who can afford care and the vulnerable poor and young women who rely on publicly funded providers.

Although Mr. Armey accurately states that A.F.D.C. funds have never been used for family planning, he again misleads. What he fails to say is that the "contract" proposes redirecting some $40 billion in A.F.D.C. monies to finance state initiatives for reducing out-of-wedlock pregnancies. This new, state-directed application of A.F.D.C. monies might well include family planning services; hence the attachment of a new gag rule to these funds.

Last, Mr. Armey contends that a full range of family planning assistance is already financed under current law. Yet in New York State, 64 percent of sexually active, low-income women and teen-agers at risk of unintended pregnancy receive no organized family planning services. CAROL L. REICHERT Acting Exec. Dir., Family Planning Advocates of New York State Albany, Nov. 2, 1994
